Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another It may be helpful for both of you to complete your signatures. There is much more to this choice than weight alone. What does "signatures" mean?
Posts.Title: Weight issues with prostate removal

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm new to this forum. I'm 56 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer 2 wks ago. My PSA was 8.07 and my Gleason score was 4+3=7. My urologist normally would recommend to have it removed, but due to my weight, he recommended radiation treatments instead. He said he would not be able to do the surgery and if that is the way I wanted to go, then would need to seek advise from a more specialized doctor in the Kansas City area. No matter what, this would be a high risk surgery with the common side effects. My concern is that if I do not have it removed now, that it would come back down the road because of my family history and my age. I'm meeting with a doctor at KU Cancer Center for a second opinion next month regarding the surgery. If I do not find someone locally to do the surgery, I am scheduled for radiation in 2 months if I decide to go that route. My main question is there anyone out there that is extremely overweight and has had the surgery done successfully? Thank you in advance for the help, I'm extremely concerned about making the wrong decision.
Posts.Title: Weight issues with prostate removal

Posts.Title: Weight issues with prostate removal

Posts.Content: I meet with the Dr again tomorrow regarding my diagnosis and treatment options. Because of my weight he had recommended radiation instead of removal. At my age, I am concerned about not having it removed, so I also have an appt at KU Med Center with a surgeon for a 2nd opinion. Looking for questions to ask other than the obvious?
Posts.Signature: DOB - 1963, 56 yrs old PSA-2015 3.79 1/18/18 - 7.06 2/7/18 - 6.85 5/9/18 - 6.08 11/1/18 - 8.07 1st Biopsy - Feb 2018 - negative results MRI Scan - Jan/2019 2nd Biopsy - Mar 11, 2019 - received diagnosis Mar/22/19- of cancer Gleason score 4+3=7. 3 cores malignant, PTI:15%, PTI=40%-Left side, PTI-10%-Right side March 27, 2019 - met with Urologist to discuss options. Due to weight, highly recommends radiation. March 29, 2017 - met with radiation oncologist to discuss procedure. Suggested Lupron shot and SpaceOar.
Posts.Title: 2nd consutation with Urologist
